title: Is the amount of CDR in league healthy or necessary?
body:
back when I started league (season 4) very very few items had CDR on them, probably not many more than 5 items. It was nice, generally no one ever had 40% CDR it was super rare to ever have more than 20. 

Now fucking everyone and their uncle has 40% CDR, in fact you usually end the game with over capped CDR. 

{{item:3001}} {{item:3194}} {{item:3504}} {{item:3174}} {{item:3060}} {{item:3102}} {{item:3812}} {{item:3147}} {{item:1400}} {{item:3508}} {{item:2303}} {{item:2302}} {{item:2301}} {{item:3401}} {{item:3092}} {{item:3110}} {{item:3152}} {{item:3025}} {{item:3158}} {{item:3109}} {{item:3100}} {{item:3156}} {{item:3165}} {{item:3107}} {{item:3800}} {{item:3065}} {{item:3069}} {{item:3071}} {{item:3078}} {{item:3083}} {{item:3142}} {{item:3050}} {{item:3157}} 

If I counted correctly 33 items have atleast 10% CDR on them many have 20% and quite a few runes also come along with CDR. 
Now I'm not saying ability spam isn't fun but is it really healthy?

Back In my day and i'm sure long before my time, people actually had to worry about saving their cds, and mana. 
I know many of you younger players won't believe this, but yes people actually used to run out of mana if they were not careful in lane, I know shocking. 
I remember the times of OLD when an Azir would do one spell rotation and be OOM in lane. I remember back in the older days when "I'm OOM" was said 100 times throughout the game. Any ways I'm getting off topic. 

Anyone back in the day, CDs mattered you would save abilities for specific times, and would often get punished if you used ur precious ulti too early. Now everyone just wiffs ultis and abilites because cooldowns are honestly not important in these days of abundant CDR. 

I personally believe for the good of league we need to go back to the days, where mana conservation mattered and cooldown reduction wasn't a stat slapped on to almost every item.

Tbh, I've played since season 4 too. Most of the current CDR existed then. The primary exceptions were the AD items that give lethality. When they or their equivalents were Armor penetration, they didn't have CDR. But, most of the other items did exist, and Mages DID get to 40% cdr quite often. And, it wasn't uncommon for Jungler AD's to at least get 30% CDR: Zephyr, Trinity, and Frozen Heart or boots.

The reason you're complaining about it now is more or less because Transcendence has made it much stronger. You can build a hybrid or tank build right now and pump in damage that didn't used to exist.

But..... then again..... you can also pump in a crap load of damage on an ADC or assassin now too. CDR damage is buffed. Lethality/Duskblade is buffed to the point ADC's rush it instead of going crit. Crit items are also buffed, twice as strong on the damage procs on Zeal items.

This isn't just a CDR problem. This is an acceleration of power from all power sources.

(for those who don't know what I'm referring to: Statik Shiv used to have about 1/2 its current pre crit magic damage, at 100 damage per proc. it was dramatically boosted about the same time they introduced Rapid Fire Cannon. At the same time, RFC can also create situations where someone without one has no counterplay).

Capping cdr on tanks was rough, cause they only had spirit and frozen heart back then, it was a choice between being able to cc more, or being able to tank more, since frozen heart isn't a good rush, and spirit only against mages, and iceborn didn't scale with armor back then.
Frozen wasn't also built often unless the enemy ran at least 2 AA based champions, but even so, tanks mostly stuck to 10% cdr at the time

For mages, it was definitely easy to cap, since they just had to run Morello + Athenes, but that hurts early game damage in favor of sustained damage like we have now, and most of the time they only run 1 or the other some mages would choose to opt out for it in favor of getting higher ap items which made them have to manage their mana more carefully in favor of burst damage, or hp + ap items, like roa and rylais, which helps in sustained battles.
So most mages would only run 20% cdr, unless they decide to go for ionian boots, and/or scaling cdr for the other 20%
APs didn't cap on cdr super easily until the mage update

Adcs had absolutely 0 access to cdr, until yommuu's became a niche popular item on them, and the adc update

Supports would run from anywhere of 10% cdr to max cdr depending on which type

In all honesty, I think assassins were the only ones that actually had optimal path to 40% cdr easily, Yommuu's, BC, ionian or cdr runes, and they could go full damage right after that.

What you say is true, capping cdr with damage is definitely new, actually it's more of capping cdr with optimal paths per class more of what it is, cause even tanks couldn't cap cdr unless they didn't want to get a health + resistance item, or a damage item, ap champs had the choice between spammability, burst or sustain for early game, but now it's more of all of them together.
The only good thing that came out of this IMO is making caster adcs viable since they get their dps increased, and supports not relying on other classes for cdr.
But most items should lose their cdr again, or have new items that have no cdr but with higher stats, so we can choose again between spammability, burst, or sustain

CDR seems to be attached to a multitude of items simply because it's the stat that Riot cares the least about when compared to Armor, Magic Resist, Damage, Ability Power, Life Steal, Critical Chance, and even Lethality.

They slap it on just about anything to accomplish two things.

1. To provide an excuse as to why the item costs roughly 3,000 gold in game.

2. To entice players into working around the CDR cap by selecting the 2, 3, or (rarely) 4 items that will provide them their max CDR.

I, however, find certain CDR items so cost effective that building more than 40% CDR despite the cap has proven efficient.

Lethality Jungle Build here.

{{item:1400}} {{item:3117}} {{item:3147}} {{item:3142}} {{item:3071}} 

Despite the items going over 40% CDR, the Black Cleaver still takes what would be 30% and makes it into 40% and seeing as how it is one of the most cost effective items in the game, the 10% CDR I do not receive isn't too big of a waste when you consider everything else the build provides.

I think items with more than 10% CDR should probably have it reduced to 10% CDR and items that already have 10% CDR are already balanced enough as it is.

This would force players to use up 4 of 6 item slots just to reach Max CDR as opposed to the minimum of 2 and the average of 3. Items that have their CDR cut could have their cost reduced. I don't know how much would be the right amount, but I figure it could be 100, maybe 200 gold.

Only reason I ever hated CDR was because it was extremely easy to max, with half of the cap available on quints and masteries alone, able to max by endgame with maybe one light CDR item if you spent Glyphs as well. Now it at least feels like a build decision. Kinda easy to me: If you are in danger of maxing, forego heavy CDR items like {{item:3071}} {{item:3165}} {{item:3078}} {{item:3025}} {{item:3115}} . Some of those could *maybe* lose some effectiveness, at least setting their primary purpose to being CDR (more akin to Frozen Heart's purpose... I don't think {{item:3071}} {{item:3078}} should be that high, at very least). If you *really* can't find a way to avoid maxing CDR, grab Sorcery as a second tree to get some bite out of the over-balance with Transcendence.

Separate notes on CDR:

Transcendence needs reworked somehow. It's nice that it's a fully CDR rune, but the two bonuses don't even interact favorably. The 10% CDR is typically used more as a bridge to fill the gap, whereas the AD/AP bonus on overdraw is intended to not only bridge, but exceed your max CDR. Those bonuses should be separate, in my opinion, as they don't tend to work together particularly well, especially since they leave champions reliant on CDR for their builds waiting for any bonus at all until midgame. The inspiration bonus is almost hands-down better, even at such a small chunk, because the bonuses actually work together with CDR dependent champions.

Also, I feel like Blue Buff could use some endgame love (since it's not even truly that good early, anyways... basically not a kill threat), and boost max CDR on who grabs it, at least by half the bonus. Endless mana is nice, but easy enough to attain regardless, so CDR maxed champs could use a little incentive to prefer it over Red Buff, instead of actually feel bad for soaking up the caster buff with little to gain from it.
